title-group.article-title: Three-dimensional deformity analysis of malunited distal radius fractures and their influence on wrist and forearm motion

abstract.p: Little information exists about three-dimensional (3-D) deformity patterns of malunited distal radius fractures including axial deformity. The current study aimed to clarify the 3-D deformity pattern of malunited distal radius fractures and reveal the influence of osseous deformities, including axial rotation deformity, on wrist and forearm motion. The deformity of 20 dorsally tilted malunions were evaluated using 3-D computer models created from CT data, and correlations between deformity components and range of motion were assessed. The 3-D deformity analysis showed that axial malalignment in pronation, which showed a correlation with the degree of radial tilt deformity, was very common. A radial tilt deformity of > 5° was observed in only 45% of cases. Although the range of wrist flexion and extension showed a correlation with dorsal tilt deformity, the range of forearm pronation and supination did not correlate with distal radius deformities.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Malunion is a common complication that occurs in patients after distal radius fractures treated with closed reduction and cast immobilization (Cooney et al., 1980; Della Santa and Sennwald, 2001; McKay et al., 2001). Patients with a symptomatic malunion, restricted wrist range of motion, reduced grip strength, late neuropathy, and/or unsightly appearance are considered for corrective osteotomy (Fernandez, 1982; Jupiter and Fernandez, 2002; Ladd and Huene, 1996; Prommersberger et al., 2002). Several surgeons have performed three-dimensional (3-D) corrective osteotomies including axial rotational realignment, assuming that anatomical reduction can give more favourable results (Athwal et al., 2003; Jupiter and Fernandez, 2002; Jupiter et al., 1992; Ladd and Huene, 1996; Miyake et al., 2011). However, these studies did not refer to a detailed deformity pattern. A method that uses axial computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for measuring axial malrotation of the radius has been reported (Bindra et al., 1997; Dumont et al., 2006; 2007), but axial rotational deformities < 35° cannot be detected (Dumont et al., 2006; 2007). To our knowledge, there have been no reports of studies that used 3-D bone models created from CT data for 3-D quantification of malunited distal radius fracture deformities. Furthermore, the influence of axial rotational deformity on the wrist and forearm is still unclear, although biomechanical studies have revealed the effects of axial malunions of the radial diaphysis on restriction of forearm rotation and instability of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ) (Dumont et al., 2002; Kasten et al., 2003; Tarr et al., 1984). The purpose of this study was to clarify the 3-D deformity pattern, including axial rotational deformity, of malunited distal radius fractures using 3-D computer models, and to reveal the influence of osseous deformities, including axial deformity, on wrist and forearm motion.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Between April 2004 and September 2011, 20 consecutive patients (four men and 16 women) affected by distal radius malunion without intra-articular malunion treated nonoperatively elsewhere were enrolled in this study (Table 1). The median age was 57 (range 18–81 ) years. All patients had sustained extra- articular fractures (AO/ASIF classification, A3). Malunion was defined as > 10° of dorsal tilt on radiographs (van der Linden and Ericson, 1981). All patients were initially treated with closed reduction and cast immobilization. After bony union was achieved, they presented to our outpatient clinic complaining of wrist pain, deformity, and/or numbness in the median nerve region. Seventeen patients (85%, 4 men and 13 women) were affected by wrist pain, 10 patients (50%, 9 men and 1 woman) by obvious visible wrist deformity, and 3 patients (15%, 3 women) by nerve problems. The mean interval between injury and review in our clinic was 12 (range 3–53) months. There was no history of trauma to the contralateral wrist in all patients. This retrospective study used CT data that had been obtained for the purpose of preoperative planning. This study was approved by the ethics committee of our institution.

For 3-D evaluation, the affected and contralateral limbs of all patients were scanned using a CT scanner (LightSpeed Ultra 16; General Electric, Waukesha, Wisconsin, USA) with a low radiation dose (scan time of 0.5 s, scan pitch of 0.562:1, tube current of 10–30 mA, and tube voltage of 120 kV) (Oka et al., 2009). Scans were performed with subjects in the prone position, shoulder in full flexion, and both limbs overhead. Although a locking system was not applied, the forearm and wrist were maintained in a neutral position. DICOM (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine) data were sent to a workstation. The 3-D bone surface models of the entire bilateral radius were created from the 1.25 mm slice digital data using an original computer program based on Visualization Toolkit (Kitware, Clifton Park, New York, USA). To quantify the deformity, the coordinate system was defined on the mirror image of the normal radius on the basis of the radius coordinate system for the hand and wrist, as advocated by the International Society of Biomechanics (Wu et al., 2005). The amount of deformity was evaluated as the distance between the mirror image of the normal radius and image of the affected radius superimposed proximally to distally (Figure 1A). This was semi-automatically performed using independent implementation of the iterative closest point algorithm for surface-based registration (Besl, 1992). We quantified the amount of deformity by subtracting the distance value of the proximal radius from that of the distal radius. The Euler angles method was used to represent the amount of deformity by the rotation angle around the unique axis established in the mirror image of the normal radius with 6 degrees of freedom (Takeyasu et al., 2011). The rotational angle around the 3 axes indicated the deformities in three directions: axial, volar–dorsal, and radial–ulnar (Figure 1B). They were defined as 3D pronation, 3D dorsal tilt, and 3D radial tilt, respectively. The degree of the three deformity components was analyzed to clarify the 3-D deformity pattern of distal radius malunited fractures. Pearson correlation coefficients were used to examine relationships among these three deformity components. Results were deemed significant if p < 0.05.

caption.p: (A) The proximal/distal part of the affected radius is superimposed on the corresponding mirror image of the unaffected radius. (B) Three-dimensional (3-D) transformation of the distal part of the affected side relative to the normal side is analyzed in the volar–dorsal, radial–ulnar, and axial rotational deformity directions, according to orthogonal coordinates of radius.

sec.p: Regarding clinical evaluation, the flexion/extension range of wrist motion was measured using a goniometer placed along the axis of rotation of the respective joints and with the forearm in a neutral position (Catalano et al., 1997). The pronation/supination range of forearm rotation was measured using the goniometer with the humerus in a vertical position and the elbow in 90° flexion (Tarr et al., 1984). To elucidate the influence of deformity components on wrist and forearm motion, we assessed correlations between deformity components (3-D dorsal tilt, 3-D radial tilt, and 3-D pronation) and range of motion (wrist flexion/extension, forearm pronation/supination) using Pearson correlation coefficients. Results were deemed significant if p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All patients showed dorsal tilt deformities of > 5° on 3-D measurement (Table 1). The median 3-D dorsal tilt was 30° (range 15°–56°). Of the 20 patients, 17 (85%) showed radial tilts with a median 3-D radial tilt of 6° (range 2°–27°). Nine patients (45%) showed radial tilts of > 5°. Three patients showed a minimal ulnar tilt with a median 3-D radial tilt of −3° (range from −5° to −3°). Therefore, 11 patients (55%) showed no coronal (radial/ulnar) tilt deformities of > 5°. The median 3-D radial tilt was 5° (range −5° to 27°) for all patients. Of the 20 patients, 18 (90%) showed pronation deformities with a median 3-D pronation of 14° (range 1°–45°). Fifteen patients (75%) showed pronation deformities of > 5°. The other two patients showed minimal supination deformities of 1° and 2°. Therefore, five patients (25%) showed no axial rotational deformities > 5°. The median 3-D pronation was 13° (range −2° to 45°) for all patients. The degrees of radial malunion deformities by 3-D evaluation are shown in Figure 2. Overall, nine patients (45%) showed dorsal tilt, radial tilt, and pronation deformities of > 5°, six (30%) showed dorsal tilt and pronation deformities of > 5°, and the other five (25%) showed only dorsal tilt deformities of > 5° (Figure 3). Among three deformity components, only 3-D radial tilt and 3-D pronation correlated with each other (R = 0.46, p = 0.04).

Deformity pattern in dorsally tilted malunion of the distal radius.

sec.p: Regarding physical examination, median wrist flexion and extension was 38° (range 0°–70°) and 63° (range 20°–90°), respectively (Table 1). Median forearm pronation and supination was 70° (range 45°–90°) and 85° (range 10°–90°), respectively (Table 1). Although forearm pronation and supination did not correlate with any deformity component (Table 2), wrist flexion showed a negative correlation with 3-D dorsal tilts (R = 0.66, p = 0.002), and wrist extension showed positive correlation with 3-D dorsal tilts (R = 0.61, p = 0.004).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The 3-D deformity analysis of malunited distal radius fractures has demonstrated a great tendency for pronation deformity, which showed a correlation with the degree of radial tilt deformity, and only 45% of patients showed radial tilt deformity > 5°. These results differ from previous reports, which suggested that the distal fragments in distal radial fracture usually tilt dorsally as well as radially, and are supinated in the axial plane (Fernandez, 1982; Gartland and Werley, 1951; Ladd and Huene, 1996). However, the description in these reports about axial rotational deformity does not originate from objective and quantitative measurements. Quantification of axial rotational deformities of the radius using axial CT or MRI has been investigated (Bindra et al., 1997; Dumont et al., 2007; Dumont et al., 2006). The only study that has evaluated axial rotational deformities by comparing the radial torsion angle of the injured and uninjured sides using axial CT images of scanning distal radius showed that 32% of dorsal malunions of the distal radius had pronation deformities, 24% had supination deformities, and 44% had no axial rotational deformities (Prommersberger et al., 2004). However, axial images may provide accurate information about axial rotational deformities only for minimally angulated cases because it is difficult to include all landmarks in one slice for cases with extensive angular deformities. In addition, axial rotational deformities of < 35° cannot be detected, even if an angular deformity is not present (Dumont et al., 2006; 2007). On the other hand, one can evaluate the deformity more precisely using 3-D computer models. Athwal et al. (2003) reported that all distal fragments were pronated (average 15°) during their clinical work on preoperative 3-D computer simulation for six cases of distal radial malunion, which is similar to our findings, which showed 90% of cases were accompanied by pronation deformity.

It is unclear whether this residual pronation is a result of the initial injury or the effects of reduction and cast treatment. Some researchers have reported that a distal radius fracture typically arises from a fall on a pronated outstretched hand, resulting in the loss of radial inclination and volar tilt as well as radial shortening (Fernandez, 1982; Gartland and Werley, 1951). Gartland and Werley speculated that fracture force makes the distal fragment pivot around the ulnar head in a supinated direction (Gartland and Werley, 1951). However, we consider that another mechanism causes pronation deformity of the distal fragment. When one falls down on an outstretched and semi-pronated hand, the fracture force is generated from the ulnar–volar side and not from the radial–volar side, resulting in pronation of the distal radius fragment (Figure 4). Furthermore, it is possible that among the other possible mechanisms, ulnar styloid fractures might also be associated with this mechanism of injury; that is, a direct blow ulnarly to the semi-pronated wrist.

caption.p: Fracture mechanism causing pronation deformity of the distal fragment. When one falls down on an outstretched and semi-pronated hand, the fracture force is generated from the ulnar–volar side and not the radial–volar side, resulting in pronation of the distal radius fragment.

sec.p: The influence of an axial rotational deformity on the range of forearm rotation in the distal radius is still unclear, although several biomechanical studies using cadavers have indicated the effects of axial malunions of forearm diaphyseal fractures on limitation of forearm rotation and DRUJ instability (Dumont et al., 2002; Kasten et al., 2003; Tarr et al., 1984). In this study, the range of forearm rotation did not correlate with the degree of axial rotational deformity of the distal radius. Several investigators have described that tightening of the triangular fibrocartilage complex is an important factor in the range of forearm rotation in distal radial malunions (Adams 1993; Crisco et al., 2007; Schuind et al., 1991). A biomechanical study of cadavers showed that disruption of the triangular fibrocartilage complex preserves the range of forearm rotation, even in cases of marked angulation and/or translation deformities, while these osseous deformities cause a limitation of forearm rotation in the intact triangular fibrocartilage complex (Fraser et al., 2009). Therefore, the status of the triangular fibrocartilage complex may be more important in the range of forearm rotation than osseous deformities in distal radial malunion.

Several experimental studies have revealed that dorsal malunion has a dorsal overload of the radial articular surface and limitation of forearm rotation (Fraser et al., 2009; Kihara et al., 1996; Miyake et al., 1994; Pogue et al., 1990; Short et al., 1987). These studies suggest that radial osteotomy should be considered for distal radial malunions with dorsal tilts over 20°. Although it remains unclear whether the correction of axial plane malunion is necessary, several surgeons have performed 3-D osteotomy with the aim of preserving anatomical configuration, including axial rotational realignment (Athwal et al., 2003; Jupiter and Fernandez, 2002; Jupiter et al., 1992; Ladd and Huene, 1996; Miyake et al., 2011). During corrective osteotomy using a palmar plate (Malone et al., 2006; Osada et al., 2007; Prommersberger et al., 2002), the plate may play a role as an axial rotational guide, and axial realignment may be attained spontaneously after plate fixation. However, in longstanding malunion, axial rotational realignment may be difficult because of remodelling of the original fracture site (Bindra et al., 1997; Jupiter and Ring, 1996). In this study, 15 patients showed a pronation deformity of 5°–45° and none showed supination deformity of > 5°, contrary to previous reports. This information is considered useful to restore accurate axial rotational alignment, especially for longstanding malunions.

In this study, we divided the deformity into three components (dorsal tilt, radial tilt, and axial rotation) to understand the degree of the deformity conventionally. However, true deformity occurs in only one vector, and it can be expressed as rotation around and translation along one unique axis (Murase et al., 2008). Therefore, from this viewpoint, the deformity can also be expressed as a rotational deformity in one unique plane (Clay et al., 2009). In our patient cohort, 25% of patients had only dorsal tilt deformity, which meant that complex reconstruction was unnecessary. Derotational osteotomy only in the sagittal plane can correct the deformity in these patients (Del Piñal et al., 2009; Henry, 2007).

In conclusion, pronation deformity, which correlated with the degree of radial tilt deformity, was very common in dorsally malunited distal radial fractures, and radial tilt deformity was observed in only 45% of cases. These findings can contribute to further improvement in preoperative planning for corrective surgery and understanding the mechanisms of deformity development.
